subject: Re: [PATCH v2 1/1] mm: numa_memblks: Identify the accurate NUMA ID of CFMW

reviews.author: Cui Chao (author)
reviews.summary: The reviewer, Cui Chao, is the author of the patch and provides additional context to clarify their previous statements about the issue being discovered on QEMU platform.

reviews.author: Jonathan Cameron
reviews.summary: The reviewer, Jonathan Cameron, initially had concerns about the patch's description of a hardware-specific issue, but after clarification from the submitter, he found it acceptable and suggested relaxing the wording to reflect that it might happen on real hardware.

reviews.author: Andrew Morton
reviews.summary: Reviewer Andrew Morton asked for clarification on the userspace-visible runtime effects of incorrect NUMA ID assignment, suggested adding a Fixes: tag to indicate supported kernel versions, and recommended updating the changelog before resubmitting.

reviews.author: Pratyush Brahma
reviews.summary: Reviewer Pratyush Brahma suggested a change to the comment in phys_to_target_node function to better reflect its new logic of preferring numa_meminfo unless the address is also described by reserved ranges.

reviews.author: dan.j.williams
reviews.summary: The reviewer, dan.j.williams, asked the submitter (Cui Chao) to provide more context on which shipping hardware platforms are affected by the issue and why a firmware update cannot be used as a solution.

reviews.author: Gregory Price
reviews.summary: Reviewer Gregory Price raised concerns that the patch implies CXL memory regions are not shipping SRAT tables, which could be correctable in firmware or a hardware issue specific to QEMU. He suggested adding a configuration option to reserve additional NUMA nodes for each CEDT CFMWS entry.

reviews.author: Jonathan development
reviews.summary: Reviewer Jonathan Cameron disagreed with the patch's approach, citing that providing SRAT Memory Affinity Structures for CEDT CXL Fixed Memory Window Structures (CFMWSs) is not necessary unless the BIOS has also programmed the full set of decoders. He suggested this could be handled by EDK2 instead.
